comments.commentBody: Never Trump.  Never Cruz.  Never Kasich.  Don't kid yourself, they're all equally bad.
The only sane path forward for America is "NEVER any REPUBLICAN" in the white house.

"Mr. Romney’s strategy worked. Mormons offended by Mr. Trump’s comments about Muslims delivered a hefty winner-take-all state to Mr. Cruz."

Never mind Trump's incessant profanity, crudeness and inability to articulate policy details to one of the most educated demographics, it was Trump's comments about suspending Muslim immigration that ended his bid in Utah. The NYT's editorial board truly resides in an alternate, self-serving universe.
Exactly. Never Trump ought to be Never Any Republican until they change significantly for the better.

I recommend to reread David Brooks' column of March 8.
Cruz would be a disaster, even worse than Trump

http://www.nytimes.com/2016/03/08/opinion/its-not-too-late.html

It is too early to call this game ... Trump will be going into the convention we know. Wait for his Vice-Presidential choice, which will likely be a real game changer.

Trump is, after all, a master of merchandising.

PS: I'm not in his camp, just watching the maneuvers.

Was this an April Fool's editorial? Why would the Times want to assist the republicans in picking the best candidate possible? After all, the Times wants Hillary as the next President. Stop advising the enemy, NYT; better to urge Trump on - that's what I do and I'm not fooling. Trump's by far the best for your candidate this Fall. Stop with the noblesse oblige already.
The Republican Party is brain-dead.

Trump says crazy things, but he really doesn't really believe what he's saying.

Cruz says crazy things -- and he really means them.

They better not choose Kasich. He's worse than the bunch because he's hidden his nastiness behind his "aw-shucks" Midwestern persona. "I'm just this nice guy here". There's nothing worse than evil hiding behind a nice mask. A wolf in Midwestern sheep's clothing

He says one thing and does the other. He says "I'm against abortion with exceptions."

What he does is "no abortions no exceptions" by tagging huge boring bills with policies that treat women's bodies has HIS property. He gets the right to say how and when the women of his state reproduces.

That's worth repeating: Do not believe that Kasich's a nice guy. Do not believe that he's a "moderate" as this column yet again says he is. Do not ignore how hie actively works to control the women in Ohio. Do not believe his Uriah Heapness of being so humble just so humble while destroying the people he says that he's serving. Do not allow Kasich to be the nominee.

This country and much of the world is going to look back and ask, "What were you doing during July 18th and July 21st, 2016?" The Republican convention may be a spectacle unrivaled in U.S. political history. A few months ago, the NYT asked readers who they thought would be the GOP presidential nominees. I can't wait to see what percentage of the NYT readership actually nailed it.

This is the craziest and scariest Republican primary in a century, preceded by the worst governance by Republicans politicians ever, all under America's first black president. Civility, facts, sensibilities and caring for our country have gone out the window under the guise of defending a dying mythology of how America should evolve.

The advantage of Cruz is when he is demolished in November, there may be a bit of useful introspection in the GOP. If Trump wins, it is very likely the Republicans will rally around the "but he was never really a conservative" flag and refuse to learn or grow for at least another 4 years. The writing was already on the wall after Romney in 2012, but the GOP has shown an impressive ability to delude themselves.

As much as it warms my heart to anticipate the GOP getting crushed in both 2016 and 2020 after the Trump nomination, it is actually bad for America to have such a dysfunctional major political party.

Don't know much about Kasich, just what I read here, but I do know that Ted Cruz is downright frightening.  He's one of those men I can't imagine a woman wanting to marry.  Everything about him screams me, me, me!!  Except, of course, for the part which worships some vengeful, punishing god. Let's face it, there is no Republican candidate we could trust with our children's future.

The fact that none of the three remaining Republican candidates is now willing to say they will support the eventual nominee shows that there is really no such thing as Republican loyalty.  Party members seems to be united mostly in their hatred for some other politician or candidate--whether that person is Barrack Obama, Hillary Clinton or Donald Trump.  It is very hard for a member of the party of "no" to say "yes" to someone other than himself.

Never underestimate your enemy! Logic, intelligence, experience, likability, electability or the lack thereof is trumped (no pun intended) by Citizens United. The USA survived W and Cheney despite the huge damage their administration caused both at home and abroad. Another GOP Presidency would have to work overtime to do worse but don't be surprised if that becomes the case. As a Democrat, I fear that the GOP establishment will nominate a candidate that is experienced, likable, electable, and a war hero with great name recognition. That's right, you guessed it: Sen. John McCain. He's the best of a bad lot and if nominated and elected, the damage will continue.

I'd suggest two things:

1. John Kasich is very, very conservative. He shares the views of the current GOP. I'd consider his election a disaster on 12 different levels--but, John Kasich is a) not nuts, b) knowledgeable and experienced. He's also been known to cut deals.

2. There's a theory out there in Republican Land that Cruz should be the candidate--not because he'll win, but because he'll lose without taking the GOP down with him, turning over the Senate, and maybe even the House.

Given that Cruz is in fact nuts, is in fact disinterested in reality, and is in fact a far-right ideologue with some extremely strange religious views (gay people should be given time to repent, THEN hanged?), that's about as good a rationale as you're going to see.

How about giving the Republican Party the room it needs -- and has needed for many years -- to implode? Why give "advice" on how to nominate a "reasonable" Republican candidate?

And imo it is basically an oxymoron. Saying things like "Only John Kasich connected with these voters" means that he can sound reasonable to the American voting public, while simultaneously proffering the same failed Republican policies that will further sink the middle class.

There has been no effort to help Kasich because Kasich should have dropped out a long time ago. He finished in single digits and in 4th and 5th place in the majority of primaries and caucuses well before the NeverTrump movement began. Kasich has still only won a single state which happens to be his home state where he is a sitting governor and he hasn't been competitive anywhere else. We keep hearing from Kasich that his best NE states are ahead of him, but the reality is that by the time these NE states come Kasich will be so far behind in delegates and wins he doesn't stand a chance. Not to mention that he isn't polling in 1st place in any of the remaining a states. Cruz has a bunch of wins and has always been the closest to Trump in the delegate count. Kasich has consistently polled nationally at such a level that he should have dropped out in February around the same time Bush dropped out. The only reason that he is polling above single digits now is because he stayed in the race far too long and he is one of only 3 GOP candidates left. Electability in November matters but you also have to win more than your own home state in the primaries. Rubio could make the same case of general election electability and he had far more delegates and more stats wins than Kasich even though Rubio dropped out weeks ago. And Rubio had consistently polled far ahead of Kasich nationally.

For all of the entertainment value Trump provides, he would still be a far better president and cause less damage to the country than a President Cruz.  A Trump Presidency would only be embarrassing.  A President Cruz would be absolutely terrifying.
Perhaps a more appropriate slogan would be "Out of the frying pan, into the fire. Vote Ted."

Financial Compromise is the Measure of the Man

With a 10% flat tax proposal Crux is no enemy of the high earners and with a payroll tax replacement Cruz is no enemy of the working poor. Cruz is simply too extreme. A higher flat tax and lower VAT is more reasonable and Cruz has actually said that he would compromise with a 12% flat tax and lower VAT if that is all he could get. Perhaps he would also compromise by keeping the Estate Tax as long as we have a large national debt.

Trump understands the important relationship between national debt and the Estate Tax. In his 2000 book “The America We Deserve” he proposed to repeal the Estate Tax and impose a one-time 14.25% wealth tax. Today Trump wants to eliminate the Estate Tax, but without a wealth tax, as the deal of a lifetime for the wealthy. It will solidify his power for the following eight years. It will be “The America We Deserve” and will “Make America Great Again” for the rich and their lucky servants. The Roaring Twenties of the 1920’s will return for the 2020’s. Trump will make the deal with a huge compromise with the Democrats.

The New York Times suggests that support for Kasich “is a more courageous path” because he is a known quantity that harkens back to the days of true compromise and well-greased wheels in congress. He won’t do anything “crazy” unless you think a balanced budget amendment will be the only way to keep the pork under control. He will certainly be a better friend of the Democrats.

I hope Trump gets the GOP nomination. Both because he represents the GOP base's dissatisfaction with its party, and because--especially after the punish-women-for-abortions comment--I think Trump will be easiest for Sanders (hopefully) or Clinton to beat. I also think Cruz is much worse than Trump, or Nixon, or Reagan, or Bush2.

I do regret that Trump is such a terrible candidate, between the nasty comments about people of various ethnicities and religions, and his apparent total lack of interest in any details of policy. Because I do think we need to reduce immigration and strictly enforce immigration laws (which hasn't been done at least since the Reagan amnesty of 1986) as per the Barbara Jordan commission on immigration reform under President Clinton.

Kasich is not by any reasonable standard a moderate, New York Times.  Please do not try to sell us that kind of snake oil.  Only by the unbelievably warped standards of the times is Kasich even close to being a moderate, and some of us remain unwarped and actually remember what a real moderate is like.

Not Kasich.... Kasich has a long history of bullying and political aggression as governer of Ohio. His newfound collegiality and saintliness need to be validated over several years before we can believe them to be genuine and long lasting; Very unlikely that they are.
Cruz is plain bad and dangerous for the country. His record speaks for itself. Trump might change for the better, but not Cruz.
Republican candidates are only a second order problem. The more pernicious problems for our country are the republican party's ideology and social misery that it has caused and continues to espouse; and its obstructionist, hateful actions against President Obama. We need an upheaval in GOP to turn over its leaders, refactor and reboot the party to be a responsible alternative. For that to happen, Trump has to be the Republican nominee, so Prez Hillary Clinton can dispatch him and current repubican leadership into oblivion.

If the Republican Party ever wants to "win" with women, it must run away from Trump and Cruz.  Both candidates reveal the inherent illogic behind interfering with a woman's personal decision to choose whether and how best to safely terminate an early pregnancy.  Trump - obviously.  Cruz - more insidiously, by trying to explain away Trump's insensitivity by issuing a formal statement, “Of course we shouldn’t be talking about punishing women; we should affirm their dignity ...."
